qas.question: What do the initials EP stand for?
Why were 45s more popular with jukeboxes?
What format was phased out by the end of the 1950s?
What was a benefit of EPs over LPs?

context: The 45 rpm discs also came in a variety known as <a0_0>extended play<a0_0/> (EP), which achieved up to 10–15 minutes play at the expense of attenuating (and possibly compressing) the sound to reduce the width required by the groove. <a3_0>EP discs were cheaper<a3_0/> to produce, and were used in cases where unit sales were likely to be more limited or to reissue LP albums on the smaller format for those people who had only 45 rpm players. LP albums could be purchased 1 EP at a time, with four items per EP, or in a boxed set with 3 EPs or 12 items. <a1_0>The large center hole<a1_0/> on 45s allows for easier handling by jukebox mechanisms. <a2_0>EPs<a2_0/> were generally discontinued by the late 1950s in the U.S. as three- and four-speed record players replaced the individual 45 players. One indication of the decline of the 45 rpm EP is that the last Columbia Records reissue of Frank Sinatra songs on 45 rpm EP records, called Frank Sinatra (Columbia B-2641) was issued on December 7, 1959. The EP lasted considerably longer in Europe, and was a popular format during the 1960s for recordings by artists such as Serge Gainsbourg and the Beatles.
